reviewText: This King Diamond DVD is getting one star only because it is a pirated bootleg disguised as an official product.  Sourced from King Diamond himself from his official website forum: [...]There will be official King Diamond/Mercyful Fate DVDs coming early next year.  Save your money!

Title: N/A

reviewText: First of all, the sound beats the hell out of my old VHS dub, as well it should...also, some alternate camera angles are utilized compared to the tape...the young David Coverdale just oozes soul on "Mistreated", which is just an incredible performance by the entire band, as is the opener, "Burn"..."Space Truckin'" does get a little tedious and noisy toward the finish...features a restored track that was not on the old VHS: "Lay Down Stay Down"...say what you will, but all in all, I only wish the state of current (2006) 'rock' was a lot closer to this.PS-On a related note: do yourself a favor and check out the great 2005 DVD by Blackmore's Night, 'Castles and Dreams'. It's a different style of music from this, but excellent nonetheless. Also, Whitesnake's 2006 DVD begins with "Burn", and is a fine hard rock show. Thanks for reading,  Ant
summary: Fine Set; When Rock was Rock!...
Title: N/A

reviewText: The infamous Deep Purple at the California Jam, what a great event.  If I were to pick either getting this on DVD or CD, I'd go with the CD.  The DVD, well the video is really disappointing.  First off, the camera work is just frickin' terrible...I mean every time Blackmore solos the camera is at his back.  And also Glenn Hughes...I love you Glenn, but man you are annoying here.  Both vocally and your in between song banter.  Those are my 2 main gripes, but they are big, and really ruin the experiencing watching this.  On the plus side, David, Richie and Ian and Jon all sound great and their performance on Mistreated is amazing.  Like I mention go with the audio experience on CD where it cuts almost all of the in between song banter and just concentrates on the music.
Title: N/A

reviewText: As the author of the Jefferson Airplane book "Take Me To A Circus Tent" and a former radio disc-jockey, I am often asked to write and or discuss various recordings from the 60's and 70's.Having been a passionate and fanatical Deep Purple collector not only with the classic Mark II line-up of Ian Gillian and Roger Glover but from the original Mark I days of Rod Evans and Nick Simper, I can see why it would be difficult for some to believe a Mark III release could distinguish itself with sush accolades.  What is impossible to comprehend is the memory loss of audio and video technology before the digital age.Before the words, CD and DVD existed record conventions were attended by the millions per year as fans searched for rare material.  They would frequently pay between twenty-five and thirty-five dollars for an unauthorized VHS recording of a live concert.  Often it would include no cover, track information and any search team did not recognize the brand of tape.Why is it repeatedly when we have the tremendous joy of reliving one of the best musical nights ever and can get the entire Deep Purple set at a good price we must complain about the audio and video glitches?This version of the famed "California Jam" brings us the complete Purple set.  Many previous copies of video didn't contain "Lay Down, Stay Down."If a day of music includes Emerson, Lake, & Palmer as well as Deep Purple let us preserve the moment and not attack the production and editing crews.Starting with the title track to their "Burn" album Purple hits the stage and creates their own California earthquake.  The classic riff is timeless and the sheer energy has the crowd fixated from the opening notes."Might Just Take Your Life" from the same record gives the audience an opportunity to judge the change in vocal styles.  The composition is shorter than its predecessor is and done a few notches in volume.  A much-underrated song."Lay Down, Stay Down" (A song from "Burn") is finally available to the masses.  Left off prior releases from overseas it fits nicely here."Mistreated" (Coming off "Burn as well) is to David Coverdale fans what "Child In Time" is to the great contingency of Ian Gillian faithful.  Coverdale places his heart and soul on stage by the time the ten-minute gem is complete.  Judge this not against Ian's superlative craftsmanship as a vocalist but strictly how you feel Coverdale pulled this off in front of a zillion folks."Smoke On The Water" from the one of a kind "Machine Head" is relentless.  From the opening riff that is recognized in every country and galaxy Blackmore's guitar explodes.  Pay homage to the great drumming by Ian Paice.  Credit Coverdale because if you listen to the vocals he never rewrote history.  The line "We all came out" is delivered "They all came out."  He is well aware that particular moment in time wasn't with him."You Fool No One" (Off the "Burn" album)/"The Mule"(From "Fireball") at over nineteen minutes is exceptional in showcasing the improvisational skills of the band.  Blackmore would be worth the price of admission but when you factor Jon Lords' perfect ability when to shine and when to hold back as well as Paice's perfect adaptation for any length tune, it only is further enhanced by the visuals."Space Truckin" ("Machine Head") is an epic.  Contains over twenty-five minutes of Purple's exploration into the far reaches of improvisation.  They are one of a handful of bands when extended songs to infinite lengths never lose the eyes and ears of the listener.If you notice Blackmore's anger, he was upset long before the camera people got too close to his face.  The initial outbreak occurred with a battle to make sure Deep Purple headlined, followed by the exact time they would take the stage.  His displeasure with camera people only elevated his anger meter once again.A quick side note.  You have read how loud Purple played at the California Jam.  They actually would surpass the disable level to record-breaking territory when they played Radio City, New York with Tommy Bolin in support of the "Come Taste The Band" tour.After 30 plus years this is the best way to relive or discover a special night from an amazing band.Enjoy the music and be well,Craig FentonAuthor of the Jefferson Airplane book "Take Me To A Circus Tent"

I think this lineup has better showmanship than MK2 - and here come the negitive reviews.  Coverdale has always been one of my favoriate singers - really rocks the house on Mistreated.

reviewText: If you want to know what went wrong with rock in the 70s, this is a good place to start.Just a year before this vidceo was shot Deep Purple had been one of the more entertaining bands on the road, but the Mk III version at Cal Jam was like a parody.  Singing songs someone else made famous is a tough gig, but David Coverdale (hilariously tormented by flying insects in this video) was a sad replacement for Ian Gillian, he just doesn't have the range or the phrasing.  Glenn Hughes who had taken over from Roger Glover on bass (and added regrettable metal-falsetto vocals) seemed to be trying to usher in the era of big hair and Spandex, he looks and sounds like he's auditioning for a role in This Is Spinal Tap.The stage was so high and the audience so far away behind chainlink fencing that it's understandable the crowd is lethargic. Coverdale vainly tries to get them clapping their hands over their heads during "Space Trucking," the few who respond were maybe covering their ears against Hughes' piercing discordant wailing.  Jon Lord produces a stunning buzzkill while introducing the new hires at great length, makes you want to yell "Shut up and play."Guitar virtuoso Ritchie Blackmore delivers a walk-through performance, concluding with a ridiculous scripted amplifier/guitar demolition.  After the obligatory guitar spinning and tossing he turns and signals the roadies to set off pyro charges in a stage-prop amplifier stack (gee, talk about spontaneous rock n' roll passion).  Blackmore then clumps back and forth pretending to throw the smouldering pieces into the crowd but actually dropping them to waiting roadies in front of the stage.  The song (and their set) finally sputters to a close when Blackmore decides there is no more point and waves to drummer Ian Paice to wrap it up.  Wow, what a climax.By the time of this festival rock was becoming theatrical and predictable, it's no wonder that punk arose largely as a rejection of this kind of stale assembly-line musical product.  If you want video of Deep Purple then get the '72-73 release, that's the real deal.  This show is a low-rent version of a once-great band just going through the motions.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Depp Purple is AWESOME!!! the song Burn, Smoke in the Water, Mistreated and Space Truckin were the BEST and LOUD!!!The ending of Space Truckin' was the most memorable scene when Richie Blackmore goes destructive and doing INSANE guitar solo.DVD:* The special features were great: they show some deleted scenes, a bonus track (Highway Star), a photo gallery, info, comments and some trivia.* The audio was EXCELENT! (sooo loud with digital sound and DTS).* About the video: Is not THAT bad as people say. In fact, the video quality looks CLEAR enough! The thing is that sometimes when the cameras goes to close-up the images look kind of smudgy because of the colors. The smudge is not SOO bad but is kind of annoying at times. BUT THAT'S IT!!! That's the ONLY small defect! The rest is PURE LOUD ROCK and SPECTACULAR solos!P.S: The 70's is the BEST ROCKING DECADE EVER!!!!!!!!!!! (just in case Im 24).Adios.
summary: ONE OF THE 70'S COOLEST CONCERTS EVER!!! and...

reviewText: I think there are two typs of fans for Deep Purple. I class them as pre Glenn Hughes and post Glenn Hughes. The pre fans are still locked into the hard charging "Smoke on the water" and will forever think this is "real" rock. While post fans realize that things must change. The sound of purple with Hughes and Coverdale brought a change to the group that was needed. The second change was added with Tommy Bolin on the "Come taste the Band", which I think was their best. This dvd is a rare look at the post Hughes stuff and is worth watching (bugs or no bugs) at the least. It just lets you see how we got where we are now in rock.

reviewText: It's tough to review this DVD. I own the Japanese VHS and the picture is crystal clear as though they were in your back yard. Why is that?  Here, on this DVD, it doesnt look like video but looks like film, very strange? The sound is good, but I am just baffled by the image quality. Clearly if you dont have this gig you should buy it, but I don't understand how my video purchased back in 1985 from Japan has perfect image quality as though you were watching it on TV, and this is looks like the equivilent of a sample rate being dropped in the digital realm? Weird. Blackmore is just so cool...even if it isnt his best performance. Now, if only someone could find the whole Castle Dnnington footage of Rainbow in 1980, now that would be incredible!
summary: Julio Erreart is right. Image not even close to Japanese VHS

reviewText: Who would have think? despite their amazing beginning with an awesome called then "screaming good looking singer" Ian Gillan and a bass player with overwhelming skills Roger Glover, Purple were able to keep and improve their musical quality with two new additions after Gillan and Glover departure, David Coverdale on vocals and Glen Hughes on bass(not that awseome this last one like Glover but the space is at least filled), the level of virtuosity of every member by the time "burn" saw the ligth was out of this world simply check out the track that gives name to the album "burn" is so speedy, melodic, technically incredible , and this song opens this California Jam 74 were among other bands such as Sabbath, Black Oak Arkansas and Eagles did their own set, the show that Purple offers is simple in visual terms but delightfull in the musical aspect, its funny how despite Coverdale and Hughes being the new ones seem to have the control of the show, they are the only ones who talk to the audience and the most expresive, however every member is magnificent in what they do Paice is an awesome drummer, Blackmore is simply one of the guitar legends of rock, Jon Lord introduced progression to hard rock for my taste and Coverdale vocals well... hard rock wouldnt be the same without him , Hughes from my point of view was the weakest addition to replace Glover, i think his performance was charisma-free, doing every effort to be noticed and nobody notices him anyway and doesnt provide any surprising element to music or remarkable skills with bass, neither doing backing vocals with Coverdale,which for me ruins in some percentage the songs he gets to be noticed, even a couple in the audience laughs at him when he scream "i dont listen anybody singing" well, from the back catalogue they only choosed "smoke on the water" wich Coverdale sings as well as Gillan, and the show ends like an apocalipse with fire, Blackmore breaking about five guitars against the speakers, and playing the strings with the floor and the feet, wow,  i wish i was there but i was just one year and a half then but Purple had the great idea to document such performance on film so i can enjoy it as well many new generations that have discovered Purples Music in this new milleniumHM
summary: Deep Purple second line up and yet God-Sized
Title: N/A

reviewText: 1974 brought the new,NEW Deep Purple with replacement vocalist and bassist Gillan and Glover sacked by replacement vocalist and bassist/vocalist David Coverdale and Glenn Hughes. Ritchie Blackmore was said to be looking for a "bluesier" sound and the album "Burn" and this concert supporting the new band and sound showcases this change.Historically (if it's even important) seems to be the change from hippie-esque psychadelia to a more metal sound on "In Rock" and "Machine Head" to a more blues based sound on "Burn". Paul Rodgers of Free (later Bad Company) was rumored to be on Blackmores shortlist for vocals for the "Burn" album and hearing Coverdale's growl, one can understand why.David Coverdale brings more of a classic rock voice to the band and puts the sound in new light, arguably better.It's amazing this video exists in any form. It's not particularly high quality and the equipment used to film shows it's limitations, from the ABC In Concert graphics to the cheesy Don Imus (yes, that Don Imus) airport introduction. Rumor has it there is ONLY one copy of the audio recording of California Jam, owned by New Yorker who recorded it from a radio broadcast as a teen.I wish demand was great enough to have the video remastered, but because of the low quality of the video, it loses a star.The concert is great. "Burn" opens the set with smoking key and guitar solos and great shrieking by Glenn Hughes. GH's vocals are a little overdone on "Space Truckin" or the impromptu that finishes "Smoke on the Water" but this man does have some pipes and his backup and harmonizing are a great compliment to Coverdales lower range."You Fool No One" is another standout, great dual vocals, a mutated guitar riff by Blackmore that later surfaces in some form on Rainbows first album, and an keyboard throttling,percussive sound that rings like a distant cousin to sounds by Yes or Santana.The drum/guitar/keyboard solos are lengthy, usually for the better. "Mistreated" wails masterfully as the California sun sets on Blackmore and the band and stoner fans color the sky with bottle rockets.The finale need to be seen to be believed, somewhat Spinal Tap-ish, but this was 1974 after all and if Blackmore bought it, he can do he wants with it.I'd love to see this whole show on DVD one day, Black Sabbath, ELP,Black Oak Arkansas, the Eagles etc. etc
Title: N/A

reviewText: Two words: Exploding amps.Three more words: Blackmore bashes camera.The sound is great and it's the DVD I chose to purchase to replace my bootleg video of the concert. Mk3 were in great form for the concert, and it deserves its legendary status.A complaint about the commentary track: much of it is word-for-word taken from the liner notes. Don't read the notes if you want to listen to the commentary track, as you'll feel cheated. Guess what happened to me... Oh well, the video's spectacular and I will cherish forever Ritchie Blackmore trashing that ABC camera.That's rock and roll, my friends.
summary: The sound is state of the art... sound.

reviewText: If all I were interested in was the sound, then I would just listen to the CD and forget the video, but I really like watching DP play, but I was really disappointed in the video quality.  I realize that this was filmed over 30 years ago; it's outdoors and dark, and filming technology was not what it is now, but one would think that the picture could have been enhanced.  The two bonus songs are just the first two songs, but only from another camera angle, and surprisingly, the video quality is better - so not sure why the rest of the set isn't.
summary: Sound is good - VIDEO IS NOT!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Deep Purple is one of the classic bands best represented by a loyal and diligent fan base. Simon Robinson, king of DP fans, has made every effort to get the most and the very best material released from the extensive archives a band like Purple have accumulated. Until now, his work has been amazing. However, I don't know what went wrong with this project. Boasting that they were working with the original ABC master tapes, promises were made that this would be the quintessential Deep Purple archive release. Hope were high that after years of substandard releases and pirate releases, that this legendary show would finally get the official release it deserved. Well, forget about that. As others here have been quick to point out, the sound is superb. The video is horrible. I don't know what went wrong, because the master tapes for the 1973 In Concert show were immaculate. Although they were heavily edited, they are in superb shape. They were shot by the same network (ABC) over a year earlier than this show, so why are these tapes in such bad shape? The picture is grainy, has major distortions, is washed out in places and the overall effect is that of watching an old, multi-generation bootleg of the concert. The close-ups are bad enough, but the shots from the boom cameras in the audience reduce the band to blobs of color on stage. There is simply no excuse for this kind of shoddy work. I have copies made from of the Japanese laserdisc and they're crystal clear. In addition to the poor picture quality, the video and audio are clearly out of synch in several places. How can that be? The old versions are perfectly synched, so what did they do to this film? A band of Purple's stature deserves better treatment than this. This is a disgrace and those responsible should be ashamed of their work.
summary: Not all it's cracked up to be!
Title: N/A

reviewText: There's something unique in this show. The vibe, the dynamics, the individual performances... everything is captured to perfection here (nevermind the generally poor video quality comparing to today's standards... This was never meant to be released as a DVD!).AS always, unfortunately, Deep Purple left a lot of great songs out of the set list, in order to perform an indulgent and overlong "Space Truckin" version, the kind of "love it or hate it" thing they did at the time.But it's great. Really, the sniffing of Glenn Hughes is sad... But the voice of the guy and Coverdale's quality are amazing. Paice also is performing at the top of his game and Lord is perfect as always.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Live In California '74" is an exciting release, probably more so than the producers realized, with loads of extras to please everyone from general rock fans, through to Deep Purple connoisseurs. I'd strongly recommend anyone with any interest in MK3 Deep Purple to get this. To those who already own the old VHS copy, do not throw it away! There are tons of different camera angles here. Though the sound quality is greatly improved on this DVD, it's still worth noting that the visuals are very different. I love all the extra bits as well, like the 8mm additions, well worth including.There's an odd bit in "You Fool No One" where we are suddenly shown images of Blackmore's soloing in the middle of the main part of the song. We then see those same images again during his solo. There are two members that make the show. First of all drummer Ian Paice, you can watch him from any angle and he is magnificent. Also Ritchie Blackmore, I have always loved his guitar playing during this period and this performance is a wonderful example of his amazing technique.It's hard not to compare this to the "Live In Concert 1972/73" DVD from the MK2 lineup (5 stars). It's almost like two different bands all together. The vibe, the vocals and feel of the music are different, but the fans (like myself) just rolled with it. I guess it's like your favorite sports team making a couple trades. You can see that the newcomers, David Coverdale (singer) and Glenn Hughes (bass & vocals) were of that younger generation of rock star, perhaps a little too "rock star" for their own good. Where as MK2's singer Ian Gillan and bassist Roger Glover didn't have to act cool and play the rock star, they just were! None the less, Coverdale and Hughes were inspired replacements for this great band to continue.Live In California '74 = 4 1/2 stars
summary: Deep Purple sitting on top of the world!

reviewText: I have bootlegs of this show that have picture quality 10 times better than this. I'm NOT exaggerating. This is so painful to watch. It's not simply the quality on each frame either. It appears as if they took out frames - it looks like you're fast forwarding through the video. It's distracting and annoying. It gives me a headache trying to watch this video. I'm particularly amused by the phrase inside this DVD warning people of purchasing bootleg versions, as they might be poorer quality. NOT A CHANCE OF THAT. I haven't seen poorer video quality of this show anywhere. The audio is decent though.

reviewText: Yes,this time,we're finally getting Deep Purple's 1974 California Jam concert complete,with the missing song "Lay Down,Stay Down",and the audio quality is decent,enhanced for surround from a mono or stereo orignal,but,for unknown reasons,the video quality is drastically inferior to any previous release.This is ostensibly from the original ABC television 2" videotapes,but,it actually looks like a very poor kinescope(Video to film transfer) with a very stuttery appearance during rapid movement.There is also a sound/picture synchronisation problem right after the layer change break,I.E. for the first 2 to 3 minutes of "Space Truckin'".This release was mastered by Deep Purple's present-day management,which is based in Australia.What were they using as a source? Though original 1980's home video releases(such as the UK videocassette on BBC Video and the Japanese videocassette on TOEI Video) were missing"Lay Down,Stay Down",at least they had the full picture quality.What went wrong on this release? I was alarmed when I heard that Eagle Rock Entertainment was going to be the U.S.A. licensee for this Deep Purple archive series,because a number of Eagle Rock's DVD releases had sound/picture synchronsation problems.My concern was justified.
summary: Great music,complete presentation,inexplicably poor video quality
Title: N/A

reviewText: In 1974, you had pop, blues, folk, oldies, proto-funk, rising disco...and hard rock. Along with Led Zeppelin, Grand Funk Railroad, Black Sabbath, and whoever else I'm leaving out, we had the band that gave us bop-bop-bommmm, "Smoke On The Water", an FM (as live) and AM (as studio) rock classic, Deep Purple.Commentary is provided, way beyond what I find necessary, as a casually interested viewer/listener - the band history (today it's gotta be called "backstory"), with all the changes for better or worse, serve the serious DP Historian.This DVD is ok with me. As its' source is television broadcast, it looks and sounds fine.Typical lousy editing - no audience interaction, despite, what, 250,000 attendees? All those California girls out there at the raceway and not one cutaway.Band seems very tired, although the music doesn't suffer - there may have been greater drummersd and bassists out there at the time, but these twp guys suffer not by comparison. A well-oiled machine, keeping the other moving parts in gear.Big hits plus one new one make the set generally worthwhile. Finale track is instrument and amp demolition. (Always hated that).
Title: N/A

reviewText: I just recently bought this DVD, and after numerous viewings, I feel that I can comment on it now. First off, I am a huge DEEP PURPLE fan. As line ups go, I liked the Mark III line up. Except for Glenn Hughes' high pitched shrieks. I am surprised that someone like Ritchie did not tell him to knock that part of his act off. He has a great singing voice and is very good on the Bass guitar. But those screams of his are just horrible. California Jam was a huge event and a mile stone for Deep Purple. Seeing them on ABC television when I was a young kid, is what got me into Purple and Rock music. So this is a very nostalgic concert for Me. They were at the top of there game for this show. The sound quality is great for most of the DVD. There are a few spots, during Mistreated that Blackmore's guitar is low in the mix, during his soft Cello style part of the song. The picture quality is pretty good, but it is not as clear and crisp as I was hoping for it to be. I've played the disk on three different DVD players, and its the same on all three. The opener is just a blistering rendition of "Burn", one of my all time favorite Rock tunes by anyone. "Might just take your life", is a great song, mostly because of Jon Lord's contribution to the track. Some really great funky hammond organ work. "Lay down stay down". Is another good song, and I liked finally seeing this done live. Its a good live track. "Mistreated", is a very good song, featuring Ritchie Blackmore, and I agree with the Narraters views on Rithchies playing at this point of his time in Purple. By the way the commentary part of this DVD, is great. Just as it is in the live 72/73 DVD, featuring the Mark II line up. If you have not bought that DVD, trust Me, you should go out and get it immediately. Now to my favorite Mark III song, and one of the best Purple songs ever, in my opinion. "You fool no One", is just a tour de force, for the three main soloist. JON, Ian Paice, and Ritchie. This is just a fantastic live song, that is classic purple. Very powerful, with musical virtuousity. And the vocal harmonies by David Coverdale and Glenn Hughes are just great. Finally the show closer, that almost got Ritchie Blackmore arrested, and Purple banned from playing in the Usa ever again, "Space Truckin" This is another great live jam song, with tons of musicianship. The sounds that Jon Lord and Ritchie Blackmore come up with, are just so cool. I have always loved Blackmore's arabian style influences, and they are very noticeable on his solo here. Finally at the end he goes crazy, smashes his guitar, into the camera, repeatedly, has his roady, the late Ron Quinton, set his amplifiers on fire, they explode twice, singeing Ritchies hair. He then drags off and throws over the stage numerous bits of sound geer. All the while the others keep playing, with Jon coming up with some really cool stuff on the synthesizers. I highly recommend this DVD. If you are a Mark III fan, its a must have. And if you just like great classic hard rock from those heady days of the early to mid 70's its also a must have as well. Thanks for listening. And by the way, if you don't know it. The band is still around, and still making great music. They are also a great live act, still. Check out 96's Purpendicular, and last years Rapture of the Deep. Two great CD's.  Take care.. Rick Woodhouse from Bradford PA USA

reviewText: Wow, I just bought this DVD and am totally blown away.  This is Ritchie Blackmore's finest hour.  Amazing guitar playing as he breaks at least three Fender Stratocasters, blows up his amp in flames, throws a guitar into the audience, throws his amp and gear over the stage, stomps on his guitar and plays with his shoes, and distroys an ABC camera with his guitar after giving it a few good wacks.  Amazing.  Throw in David Coverdale's first trip to the States, Glenn Hughes on bass, Jon Lord in fine form and the awesom Ian Paice, and you got a DVD that blows the roof off.  If you love the Guitar and Rock and Roll, this is a must-have.

reviewText: The band is very good, not great, but very good. The filming and sound is very bad, but then again that was 1974. We are lucky to have that. This was my favorite configuration of the band, David Coverdale and Glenn Hughes both singing. The songs were better when they recorded "Stormbringer", but that wasn't out yet. Blackmore throws one of his tantrums at the end, not impressive, as a player myself I can't bear to watch good equipment be smashed and burned in these spoiled tantrums these guys pull. I've been in the business fifty years and watching them throw these tirades just makes me mad, yes I'm jealous I'd like to be in their shoes and if I was I would be thankful and grateful rather than act like a spoiled child.As I said, the band is very good, the filming and sound leave room for improvement, but afterall this was 1974, I feel lucky, as a fan, just to have found this.

reviewText: The last reviewer said it all. This is a great concert, from a great Deep Purple era. But they ruined this disc. The transfer is horribly poor, and looks like it is from a bad videotape that was transferred from PAL to NTSC, not professionally, so it has that jumpy quality.I was very excited to get this new disc as I had one of the Brazilian boots of it for years.While this disc has some interesting extras, and is a dual layered DVD-9, and has a missing song, it is ALL wasted on the horrible video transfer job they did. It looks like a VCD it is so bad.The band should be embarrassed that the unauthorized overseas versions of this show look MUCH better than this.I'll probably never watch this disc again as the Brazilian version I bought from Ebay years ago looks MUCH better.There has got to be a much better master of this show than this.Let's hope they pull this coaster and remaster it the RIGHT way.I just don't understand it. My advice is to go on Ebay and get one of those overseas boots of this disc because they are of a MUCH better quality than this piece of junk.
summary: Excellent Performance, REALLY BAD video transfer!

reviewText: First, a technical note:  footage from both shows was videotape, NOT film.  Liner notes indicate the concerts were filmed, but it's not the case.  This makes a huge difference in dealing with rock footage from the seventies, as the norm was grainy, dark picture and typically out-of-sync sound with film footage  ( especially early seventies shows ).  The B & W footage from 1972 is stunning in its clarity...looks like four hundred line resolution, which means the source tapes had to be the original two-inch videotapes.  Ian Gillian's a bit hot in the mix, but otherwise great audio as well.  The biggest problem with the black and white Copenhagen show was that the video director apparently wasn't very familiar with Purple's material, or he would've known when the lead guitar solos were coming up to have the right camera feed going on tape.  Remember that camera fades were done live, versus in post production during recent years.  The color video resolution from '73 actually looks a bit "soft", albeit still very good, compared to the crisp B & W resolution of 1972...ABC probably edited the 1973 "In Concert" footage to 3/4-inch tape, resulting in the slight loss of video quality  ( albeit in color! ).  It's shame the moguls at ABC didn't recognize the future value of keeping original rock footage intact, also evidenced by their decision in 1978 to erase all of the legendary California Jam broadcast masters...as to performance, my biggest surprise was in just how good Ian Paice is on drums.  His solo on "The Mule" has to be seen to be believed.  I'm not sure why Ian Gillian bothered hammering away on congas, as you mostly can't hear them in the mix!  Richie Blackmore was phenomenal as always...at least he refrained from bashing one of the video cameras at this point in his career.  This DVD is a bonanza for DP fans everywhere.  Highly recommended.

reviewText: After producing a string of groundbreaking albums in the early 70's, Deep Purple, one of the biggest names in heavy metal underwent a major lineup change in 1973, with the departure of vocalist Ian Gillan and bass player Roger Glover.  Vocalist David Coverdale and bassist Glen Hughes, two relatively unknown young colts, replaced them, and together with guitarist Ritchie Blackmore, drummer Ian Paice, and organist Jon Lord, recorded Burn (1974), an incendiary album that featured the classic Purple sound, blended with some soul and blues, and delivered with rejuvenated energy.In the tradition of Woodstock, The California Jam was a music festival held at the Ontario Motor Speedway, in Ontario California (4/6/74).  Drawing close to 200,000 fans, the massive event featured eight acts, including Black Oak Arkansas, Black Sabbath, Rare Earth, The Eagles, and Earth Wind and Fire.  Co-headlining were Deep Purple, and the progressive rock trio Emerson Lake And Palmer (ELP).  With the album Burn having recently been released, the Cal Jam was a big gig for Deep Purple, and the band responds with a terrific performance.  Newcomers Hughes and Coverdale are remarkably loose, handling the singing chores, and interacting with the huge audience.Musically, there is little to complain about, as the band is very tight, and they smoothly run through an 85 minute, seven song set, that contains five selections from Burn.  As is traditional for Deep Purple's live performances, some songs feature arrangements with plenty of room for improvisation and extended jams.  The bluesy Mistreated, and the funky You Fool No One, join Space Truckin', as the songs where the band really gets to stretch out, particularly Lord and Blackmore.  David Coverdale appears very confident, and not the least bit intimidated, but the future Whitesnake frontman still seems to be overshadowed at times.  It's quite natural, given the magnitude of the talent that he is playing with.  And there's no backdown in Glen Hughes, who takes command on the stage.  His trademark voice even overpowers Coverdale's at times.  As always, steady Ian Paice anchors the band.What is most unfortunate is that this historic performance is not captured very well on video.  Perhaps due to the technical limitations of the equipment at the time, image quality is often terribly soft and out of focus.  Camera coverage of the stage seems to have been inadequate, resulting in bad shooting angles.  Worst of all, a horrible job of editing job was done.  The choices of what views to show, and who to feature, are often totally wrong, misdirecting the focus of the performance.  Since much of the material was new, the production crew was probably unfamiliar with the music, however even allowing for this and the limitations of the venue, and the inadequate camera coverage, the way the concert was edited is still exceedingly poor.  You would think that even an idiot would know that when guitar god Ritchie Blackmore takes a solo, you put a camera on the man in black.  If the guitarist moves away from the camera closest to him, switch to an alternate camera, don't show a view of his back!  Throughout the entire performance, you rarely get to see Blackmore playing his signature passages and licks.  The editing choices are outrageously bad, with too many shots of the crowd and rear views of the band.  Even when the camera is focused on the appropriate person, like Coverdale or Hughes singing, the angle is often not the best.  The poor video quality combined with the bungled amateurish editing job, make this performance both disappointing and frustrating to watch.Fortunately, the sound mix seems to be well balanced, and the audio quality is very good.  Deep Purple was clearly entering a new era, opening the show with Burn, Might Just Take Your Life, Lay Down Stay Down, and Mistreated, new songs from Burn, that the bulk of the audience was probably unfamiliar with.  After cranking up the crowd with Smoke On The Water, the performance concludes with epic versions of You Fool No One, and Space Truckin', as the band shifts into high gear.  Ritchie Blackmore's legendary destructive excesses are documented, as he destroys a guitar and tosses it into the audience, trashes several speaker cabinets, and slams a guitar into one of the onstage cameras, putting it out of commission.For fans of Deep Purple or 70's heavy rock, their Cal Jam performance is definitely worth seeing.  The Mark III lineup has plenty of energy, and is quite inspired onstage.  Sadly, the brilliance of one of the finest heavy rock acts of the era, has not been captured very well.  While having some video is definitely better than nothing, it is a shame that better results were not achieved.
summary: a historically significant DP Mark III performance, that sadly is not captured very well...

reviewText: As a huge Ritchie Blackmore/ Deep Purple/ Rainbow/ Blackmore's Night fan, I was very impressed with this dvd. yes, some vhs versions have somewhat better video quality...but who cares? This release more than makes up for that with outstanding AUDIO, bonus clips, etc. Get this asap!
summary: Well worth your time and money

reviewText: The show is ok. However, the ABC cameramen who filmed it are absolute morons: Blackmore plays solo-they show Glenn Hughes, then they show the back of Blackmore's left hand, Ian Paice plays solo-they show his back and then the crowd.In a couple of places, Hughes' falsetto is obvious nonsense. Coverdale should not have sung "Space truckin'": there is no comparison between his perfomance of this song and Gillan's in "Made in Japan"(Gillan's perfomance is so "spacetruckingly" better). "Smoke on the water" is screwed up, because Hughes could not stay away from the mike too long and started to sing along with Coverdale. Blackmore's solos are a wreck. Especially in "You fool no one". It seems as if he did not know what to play or simply did not care about it. He started all his solos with a tremolo, and this was really bad. No comparison between his studio and live perfomance. In fact, he is one of the worst live guitarists. Picture quality is suspiciously poor, and I do not think the technology is to blame.
Title: N/A
